description.text: If you've built a working RepRap, it's pretty safe to say you've earned this one.

title: 2-axis GoPro Gimbal v3.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
7/20 Added generic frame mount
7/23 Added custom frame mount
[12.5mm holes, 50.5mm spacing] This is a 2-axis GoPro gimbal made to support the Gopro while mounted inside of the polycarbonate enclosure. The mounts are designed to work with the Xaircraft DIY frames. The roll mechanism works on a rail system and a series of gears that take the +/- 90 degrees of servo travel and rotate the inner ring by +/- 55 degrees. The pitch mechanism is directly driven from the servo. The mount is made to use Xaircraft rubber rings for vibration damping. If you would like to see the mount redesigned to meet alternative specifications you can contact me with dimensions at [email protected] Keep in mind that this was designed to be printed in polyamide using a zcorp printer. The attributes of this material are as follows: Layer thickness of 0.1mm with a detail resolution of 0.2mm and a recommended wall thickness of 0.7mm. If the printer uses support structure, the material must be able to dissolve away. More information found here:
http://polakiumengineering.com/?p=1146 This is only a prototype and hasn't been tested because I don't have access to an affordable source for 3D printing it.

The following items are not included and must be purchased separately:
[Qty. 2] 9G EXI Digital Metal Geared Servo
[Qty. 2] 3x7x3 Ceramic Ball Bearing You will also need a suitable bolt for mounting the GoPro to the gimbal. The gimbal connector is designed to fit the polycarbonate GoPro enclosure just as any other gopro mount does, however, the stock bolt handle is too long. Assembly is fairly simple, much of the gimbal is already assembled.
1.) Insert the roll bearing into the inner ring.
2.) Insert the 35 tooth gear into the roll bearing with the 10 tooth gear facing away from the bearing. Be sure that the roll ring is properly centered along the rail before the 35 tooth gear is meshed with the outside ring.
3.) Fix the 30 tooth gear to the roll servo, center the servo, and then either bolt or glue the servo to the inner ring.
4.) Insert the pitch bearing into the middle ring.
5.) Attach the pitch servo to the outer ring using either glue or bolts.
6.) Center the servo and insert the servo gear into the hole opposite the pitch bearing.
7.) Use the screw supplied with the servo to fasten the pitch servo gear to the gimbal.
8.) Insert the pitch pin opposite the pitch servo and glue it in place.
9.) Now the rubber dampers can be inserted into the gimbal mounting holes and the gimbal can be attached to the loading pipes of the frame.

comments.author: PolakiumEngineering

comments.text: I have worked with the Dimension 1200 series, a similar 3D printer to yours, but I still see issues arising from printing this model unless a dissolving support structure is used. I had originally planned to outsource the printing to be performed by a Zcorp 650, and in order to keep the material costs low I used thin walls with very fine tolerances between parts, tolerances that can't be achieved on many professional printers, let alone hobby grade printers. I look forward to seeing what you manage to produce
comments.author: antpgomes

comments.text: I understand what you're saying and with the current design I agree...however I just realized one thing...to mount the gopro, I can just print the "...print.stl" file right? or any other parts in the other stl's are necessary?
comments.author: PolakiumEngineering

comments.text: Correct, the other parts are just separated off with the exception of the generic frame mount. They are actually designed to be printed as a single part, such that the rails along the inside are printed within each other. The tolerances between these rails are very fine. I can't recall the exact dimension, but I believe it is between 0.3mm to 0.7mm. The parts will require some sort of modification in order to assembled the rails if they are to be printed separately.

I made my own copy of the Pitchcar game and needed some rails. The track pieces have the same size slots as the original game pieces. Through a little trial and error I was able to come up with a rail profile that wedged itself nicely into the track pieces. The top of the rails are about 3.4mm wide and have a wedge profile toward the bottom that narrow to about 2.4mm. They straight rails are 21.5cm long and the curved rails about 26cm along the arc.

remixed_from.author: Smirf123
remixed_from.title: Han Solo Blaster Please Read Change Log

title: Han Solo Blaster - Optimized for printing

description.text:
I just read the comments on the original Thingiverse posting (not sure how I missed...)

  • This is a blaster is a design for Han Solo from Star Wars
  • Designed originally by Alan Stanford
  • Original site:https://www.myminifactory.com/object/hans-solo-blaster-2488

I have to say this is likely the favorite piece I've printed to date. Thanks to Smirf123 for sharing the design on Thingiverse where I found it... with the exceptions below, I didn't make changes to this wonderful design.

Changes:
1) I broke apart the breach.

  • I printed the trigger upside down with support only around the trigger
  • The coil in front of the trigger box is now a separate item and can be printed coils up with supports to base, but not touching any external feature (very clean to print) and it slides right onto the trigger portion in the same manner as the rest of the build.

2) I made the sight hollow... it's a sight after all, you should be able to look through it. (print it in black vertically - clean printing, and faster). I also took off the adjuster knob off the sight and made it a separate part, meaning no supports for the sight, and an easier print.

3) I noticed that the Blaster Tip fit loosely... so I designed an adapter which snugly fits on the blaster "top" and allows the Tip to slide on snugly.

4) I separated the handles as I like to print 1 piece at a time... no other reason.

Note: I printed all parts as shown in the images above, except the "Top", which is showing on it's side... I printed it right side up, with supports.

Lately I've been seeing a lot of people printing 20mm cubes as forms of calibrations. Which is great to hone in your Outside Dimensions! But why print a bunch of different "calibration" pieces? So as simple as it is (and why I didn't think of this sooner), I bring you my version of the XYZ 20mm Cube. Which can teach you a lot about your own printer! Outside Dimensions, Inside Dimensions, Shrinkage, Retraction, Supports. Not just your plain ol "let me take 3 measurements from a single print" but yet in the same print you were already going to print! And at less filament!

This is a 20x20x20mm cube with 10mm holes bored through the center of each axis.

Print at any resolution, any infill, with or without a raft. Simple goal is for you to see what your printer does and to understand it. Calibrate your retraction to what looks best for your plastics. Calibrate your supports to what you like or see how your plastics handle overhangs at the top of a circle. Understand the shrinkage of your plastics when you make holes, so you know what to expect when making fitting parts.

Remember folks. If you have a discrepancy, DO NOT automatically assume e-steps. You only printed 1 object. Theoretically, you need to print multiple sized objects to see a percentage issue in your machine. So tape a ruler to any axis, and a needle or toothpick on your extruder. Then send commands to move. If its a percentage issue, it will be multiplied from the 20mm object to the full length of your printers movements. If its the same discrepancy, you most likely have a mechanical problem, loose belts, worn parts, goblins living under your printer, also you can have an extruder e-steps issue, over/under pumping, giving thick/thin walls which can give you a constant outside/inside dimensional issues.

Adafruit's box is a cool concept that can be made more durable and customized with 3D printing.

This is version one, designed and printed out in one day. There are lots of improvements that could be made so the SketchUp file is included for users to customize and build on this design.

There is a spot for placing a piece of metal and a magnet to help keep the lid closed. It can use some improvement. The hinge uses a piece of 1.75mm filament pushed through. You can glue or friction weld it into place. This print required a little drilling to fit the filament in.

description.text:
First Test Flights - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=doQxB7YVR6k
Better Footage Compilation - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lobxmQwVfg0 The "Scorpion 2" is a tricoper designed by a friend, Ricardo Fernandez and me. A GoPro can be mounted in the front directly onto the body without any extra mounts required. The tricopter can also be used for FPV Flight and capturing some great footage. --- UPDATE ---
"Scorpion 3" is currently being designed. It's a sleeker version with Carbon Fiber landing gear mounts and where most of the electronics and wiring are inside. It's expected to be printed and tested by the second week of January. ---- IMPORTANT! ----
You can just download the CCv2-full.thing file and make it if you just want this as soon as possible. But I've also uploaded individual stl files if you'd like to print them separately and also the CATIA Part files if you're interested in making modifications. Make sure you publish them under the CC-BY-NC (Non-Commercial) License though. Additional Parts Required:
3 x 1/2" Dia. 1' long Carbon Fiber (aluminum and wood can be used too) tube
5 x 3M Dia. 1" long Wood Screws
6 x 3M Dia. 1.5" long Bolts
16 x 3M Dia. Lock Nuts
2 x 3M Dia. Wing Nuts
4 x 3M Dia. 1" long Bolts The above parts can be bought from R/C hobby stores and/or Hardware stores. I got he Carbon Fiber spars from McMasterCarr and the other parts from True Value. You should be able to get all of the above parts under $50. Recommended electronics:
3 x High Performance T-Motor 1100kV Brushless Motors - $29.90 ea. (http://www.hobbypartz.com/02p-motor-375-ms2216-kv1100.html)
3 x Detrum 25A ESCs - $10.50 ea. (http://www.hobbypartz.com/60p-dye-1002-25a-esc.html)
1 x 11g Metal Gear Servo - $4.70 (http://www.hobbypartz.com/33p-solarservo-a107.html)
1 x 11.1V (3S) 5000mAh 40C Sky LiPo Battery - $48.92 (http://www.hobbypartz.com/77p-sl5000-3s1p-40c-3333.html)
1 x KKMultiCopter v5.5 Flight Control Board - $17.96 (http://www.amazon.com/KKmulticopter-Program-Programmer-Firmware-Loader/dp/B006U9KX2K/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1386739501&sr=8-1&keywords=kkmulticopter) NOTE - You can also use other boards like the KK2 flight control board. They will fit as long as they have 4 x 3M screw holes 45mm apart. Optional electronics:
GoPro Hero 3 camera with case - $199 (http://gopro.com/cameras/hd-hero3-white-edition)
5.8 GHz FPV System - $299 (http://www.hobbypartz.com/05p225-fpv-system.html) Approx. Total Cost (without GoPro or FPV) - $250 I'll upload some pictures of the final build soon btw.

To assemble the "Scorpion 2" tricopter, use the 1.5" bolts and lock nuts to hold the spars to each mount and for the tail spar to the body. Use the 1.5" bolts and wing nuts to connect the left and right spars to the body. This is so that it can easily be dissembled for portability. Use the 1" bolts and lock nuts to mount the motors onto the motor mount parts. Cut off one of the servo's (the one by where the wires come out) connector extensions and use a wood screw to attach the servo to the housing. Use 1.5mm screws or push rods to connect the servo arm to the tail motor mount. Use 4 wood screws to attach the Flight Control Board onto the body. If you're using the KKmulticopter v5.5 board, use the Yaw Gyro Protector to keep it from breaking. It's a pretty fragile part. Use velcro straps or zipties to attach the battery to the bottom.   
Make sure you clean out the supports from the parts after printing them.  
There is space inside the body for the power distribution system. There are also 4 slots for wire sets.  
Follow the image renderings if you need to.

title: Third Hand - Helping Hand - Solder Assistant

description.text:
I was looking at the complete third hand with base, and didn't like how small it was, and also it was pretty expensive for what it is. So I just bought the hands and drew up this base to print.

You can also download sections for the arms and print the whole lot if you're really keen. I figured at $3-4 for the whole thing, including alligator clips, it was worth just buying them.

The larger size (right on 200mm) is for if you are glueing the arms in, the hex area is .5mm wider (face to face). If you have a resoldering air gun or something that can get the base to soften after it's printed, use the smaller size, and then heat the hex area on the base, and push the arm in that way.

This little trolley can be used to do some video travelling effect, video reveal effect on a table, 360 views, cool effects on a 31st of december day on the table !

i used the phone holder from my selfie stick to hold my smartphone. A camera with standard 1/4 inch hole can be fixed on it.

Note that it can be used like a tripod ; leave it on the table, and attach the camera or smartphone on it...

the mount is a standard 1/4 inch screw .
Note 2 : there is a specific procedure to print the screw : as soon as it is finished, do nt let it cool down, immediately screw it to a camera , to form correctly the screw. If you do not do this, the screw will not work.

Requirements :

i used some plumber joints that i had for the wheels : dimentsions are :
external diameter : 30mm
internal diameter : 21mm
Thickness : 2mm
If you dont have them, the trolley will probably work as well, but being less steady...

I used 1 M3, 4cm rod.
and 5 small wood screws ( 13mm)

Can't be cheaper.
...

As the wheels are printed, it is good to review the parts carefully, and sand any print glitches, ...

Ideally this should be remix to use ball bearing, but this first release is good enough to play with a cheap toy.

the fix on the wheels, are purposely tight. you need a tool to fit them.

i used a hammer to put the 2 parts of the wheels together. and a clamp to put the fix on the suspension.

description.text:
While building a Core XYZ frame I found that the surfaces where two Aluminum piece's met were not always aligned with each other. This made alignment of the two ends of parallel rods hard. So I put this part on all joints to keep the surfaces aligned with each other. There is some structural strength but not much. The primarily purpose is to make sure the surface are aligned. You will still need to support the joints with 90 deg. angle buckets.

Both the printer file and the source file are included.

author: Chytry

description.text: This is an adapter cable that lets you use normal headphones with Google Glass and a 3d printed mount to hold the adpater in place.  The 3d printed mount keeps the headphone plug behind your ear but more importantly, isolates the micro-USB from mechanical stress.

To use regular headphones with Google Glass, you need a micro-USB to 3.5mm plug adapter like this one: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CMDGSX6/ . A 500K ohm resistor must be soldered between pins 4&5. The USB side of the cable I received above could be opened by unsnapping some latches (providing easy access to the back-side of the usb connector), but your mileage may vary. The pinout for the back of the plug is available here http://beyondthekeeboard.wordpress.com/2010/10/30/hacking-away-with-android-pt-2-making-your-own-usb-host-cable/ (see step 3, backside image). After soldering in the resistor, I used heat-shrink tubing to cover the resistor and enlarged hole I had to make to get everything closed again. I printed the clip with .4mm layer height using ABS so the curved arms had some flexibility. Because the hot-bed contact area is small, you may need to use a brim. I also needed to use a fan to get the print to look decent. The 3.5mm plug snaps into the curved part of the object, and the rectangular opening slides over the fat end of the Glass.

title: Thing O Matic Y Axis Bearing  Mod

description.text:
This modification for the Y axis was inspired by www.thingiverse.com/thing:6184 and uses the same brass tube to increase the distance between the bearings on the Y axis.
My XY carriage was a bit sloppy due to one of the sleave bearings being loose and this mod fixed the problem.

Go look at www.thingiverse.com/thing:6184 for tips on cutting and shaping the brass tube and increasing the diameter of the carriage holes. I used a step drill bit held in my hand that worked very well.
Cut the 21/32" brass tube to 95mm which leaves 10mm either side of the carriage. Make sure the ends are flat and square.
Remove Y shafts and belt. You probably don't have to entirely remove the XY carriage, just allow enough room to work. I removed it because I wanted to tighten the idler bearings at the same time.
Remove bearings
Enlarge bearing holes to allow snug fit and insert brass tube.
Carefully push bearings into brass tube.
Add some lubricant as part of the shaft will be inaccessible.
Reinsert shafts and reattach belt. Some jiggling of the self-aligning bearings may be necessary to get the shaft through.

title: Magnetic Effector & Carriage & Double 50mm radial Filament Cooler for Delta Printer (E3D V6 mount)

description.text:
Work in Progress!

To increase the effective hight of my delta printer, the E3D V6 hotend has to move up.
Some additional requirements are:

  • possibility to add up to three filament cooling fans (tbd. will be added later)
  • integrated 30mm fan for the heatsink
  • quick exchange (e.g. with an indicating caliper, or different nozzles)

As magnets I use six N52 type, 14mm diameter with 3mm hight.

Used screws are:

  • 2x M3x15mm (fan)
  • 4x M3x10mm (E3D V6 Mount)

Future updates will include an caliper add-on, as well as the files for filament cooling with 50mm radial fan.

Until to the next update you have to glue the top and bottom circle.

UPDATE:

2017-02-06:

  • uploaded the top and bottom circle for the dual 50mm radial fan mount

  • uploaded the lock to hold the bottom circle at the effector

  • uploaded the Effector V5 with stability improvement and a better fitting for the 30 mm fan.
  • added the Slider V5 using a nose on the upper side for optical Endstop and N52 type neodymium magnets 14mm diameter x 3mm hight.

author: hoaze

description.text:
first version of a hyperbolic funnel to produce "engergetic water" :)
properly for random water faucets

print_settings.Notes:: PLA

description.text:
There are a few self watering planters on thingiverse, but they do not fit the herbs I buy in supermarkets! If I want them replanted I have to go and find soil and make a mess of the sink/table.
Also I find the water indicators lacking in functionality (if there are any).

I've tried to create a set (range, if you will) of self watering planters sized to fit herbs plants you buy in stores (in Denmark) with a water gauge to make it easy to water the herbs just right.

I mainly see two sizes; the 'small' ones typically contain chives (purløg) or parsley (persille), and the 'normal' ones containing basil (basilikum) or organic herbs in general.

February 2018: Experience/lessons learned (after about a year of use)

  1. Glue sucks - sometimes it doesn't bind properly and the bottom of the pot will come loose (e.g. while trying to clean the bottom of the pot) - I will be trying a twist-on approach.

  2. Emptying the bottom of the pot from soil is difficult - it requires a tool and may cause it to come of the pot - the bottom has be removable.

  3. Tilted bottom - it is not tilted enough to have an effect anyways - make the inside of the pot flat.

  4. Pot corners are difficult to clean - the sharp edges makes it easy for soil to stay behind - round the corners of the pot.

  5. Frequency of refill - once a plant reaches a surtain size it drinks enough water that that the reservoir has to be refilled daily - make a version with a larger reservoir.

  6. Refill requires funnel - the refill hole is too small to resonably be filled without help - make refill/water gage hole bigger

  7. Takes up space - when not in use the pots take up a lot of space as they do not stack - make pots slightly conical to make them stack

  8. STL file names are relatively long - my print app will only show about 20 characters so the significant part of the name has to be within that number of characters - use "SWHP" has a prefix in stead of "Self-watering"

  9. Use with Växer - I made variations of the pot to be used with my Växer system from IKEA - make a screw on-bottom that works as an adapter for the Växer holes to avoid having two types of pots

Printer:

Sculpto

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal (0.25mm)

Notes:

PLA

Inspired by IKEA self watering garden system (VÄXER)

I have the VÄXER system from IKEA and I really like the clear indication of when water is needed. (The system is for growing new plants and therefore also does not fit my herbs.)

Water indicator from IKEAs VÄXER-system Thickness

I did a few tests and I was fairly happy with a 1½mm thickness so I have used this thickness for both the bottom and the walls.
I find it to be sturdy enough to feel secure.

Print or plastic?

You can either print the reservoir or you can reuse something many danish households already has: a Carte D'Or ice cream container.

Print a reservoir or use a plastic container. Printed reservoir

Make sure to test that the reservoir holds water! If it does not holder water straight off the printer you will need to find a way of waterproofing it.
For this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:903411 they recommend a wood glue suitable for cutting boards.
I've also heard boat varnish (skibslak) recommended for waterproofing. (In Denmark there is a product called Vandglas from Borup which if supposed to be able to waterproof clay jars and such, but I have not found it effective on my PLA products)

Plastic container as reservoir

If you go for the ice cream-option: Cut holes in the lid:
90mm diameter hole for a 'normal'
65mm diameter hole for a 'small'
27mm diameter hole for the water gauge.

If you do not have a lid over the reservoir the water will evaporate and you will have to refill the water more frequently.

So many parts

You will need glue!

To make the pots usable for pre-grown herbs I do not have the luxury of having a tilted bottom, so rather than waste a hole bunch of filament to make the pot printable as one piece with a relativly flat inside I've gone with the 'you will need glue'-approach.

Each pot consists of two parts: Pot Bottom (same for all) and Pot Top (sized for the herbs) which must be glued together.

Pot Top 'Normal' (Ø90mm), Pot Bottom, Pot Top 'Small' (Ø65mm) Using the Pot

You may be thinking: What goes in the bottom?

The answer is: something that can absorb and release water. You can use soil or materials for soil-less planting or, my on hand favorite; a cotton cloth (like from a cut up t-shirt or old dishtowel (viskestykke))

Replanting step by step (using a cotton cloth)

  1. You will need:
    A herb plant
    A Pot that fits the herb plant (bottom and top part mush be glued together and dry!)
    A Cloth (note: if you are using another material add it to the bottom part and make sure it covers the bottom of the top part and skip to step seven)

  2. Grab the center of the cloth and hold it approximately 40mm from the center (the height of the bottom part of the pot)

  3. Fold the rest of the cloth back over to make a section of the cloth thicker and thus filling the bottom part.

  4. Mash the cloth together and get the pot ready

  5. Put the folded end of the cloth into the bottom part. You may want to use a stick/pen to ensure that the cloth has been pushed all the way down to the bottom of the hole!

  6. Spread out the ends/corners of the cloth to cover the bottom.

  7. Take the original plastic pot off the plant and put it in your printed pot.

  8. Done and ready to put in a reservoir!
Water Gauge

While you want your reservoir to be waterproof, but you need the gauge to be airtight!

The Gauge works by trapping air, which makes the gauge float. If air can creep its way out, the gauge will not work as intended!

For the same reason the gauge has to be kept vertical while in the water. In the printed reservoir there is a round section to ensure this. If using a plastic container print the gauge house.
In either case you will also want a lid for the water gauge. The lid ensures the measuring stick is centered and easy to read. It also keeps the gauge from tilting (which would let out air).

If your gauge 'sinks' you can do one of two tings:

  1. Live with it and always lift the gauge before reading the water level
  2. Make the gauge airtight

The top bump is 'minimum water level' while the lower bump is 'maximum water level'.

Water Gauge sealed with coloured nail polish making it easy to guess where air was seeping put. Water refill

The hole used for the water gauge is also intended to be used for refilling water, this is why there are slids in the sides of the loose gauge house and there is an outcropping in the side of the reservoir.

I made a experimental funnel "Water refill". The idea is that you replace the lid with the funnel which helps you fill in water while still being able to read the water level. When done, put the lid back on.

If your water pouring skills are better than mine, you may be able to do without; simply pour water till it reaches the top of the point inside the gauge-hole.
Just be sure to pull the gauge out of the water when done as there will have been nothing to keep it from tilting (and loosing some air) while you have been filling water in there.

author: MJLion

description.text:
The stock QX70 prop sits too low in the duct. I designed a very simple part that will help lift the motors so the props have enough clearance. It's a little more elegant than using hot glue and certainly looks better.

There are two versions. The original raises it up by about 2-3mm. The "tall" raises it up an additional 3mm. You may want to experiment to see which ones work best for you.

Printing Instructions:
I used .20 layer height
You will need a nozzle that is .40 or smaller to print this, as the walls are very thin. If your slicer struggles with printing the full model, check your nozzle settings. You may be able to adjust the nozzle size manually to .40 or less.

You should be able to use just about any filament for this. I'd recommend ABS or a flexible filament so it holds up better in crashes, but even PLA should work.

These don't even register on my digital scale. When printing with PLA, my slicer tells me the plastic weight is .38 grams.

Installing Instructions:

  1. Remove propeller, and the rubber band that holds the motor wires.
  2. Lift the motor out of the holder, being very careful as you lift it so you don't damage the duct supports. No need to unplug the motor, but be careful not to push the motor with too much force, as you don't want to damage the wiring.
  3. Drop the prop riser into the motor holder.
  4. Shift the prop riser so it sits on top of the peg. Keep the wires out of the way so they don't sit in between the motor and the riser. There should be plenty of room for it to sit on.
  5. Push the motor back down into the holder. It should sit on top of the prop riser.
  6. Add the propeller back on and you should be good to go!

Hope you enjoy this. If you have any suggestions for improvement, or other ideas, please leave them in the comments.

title: Fitbit Charge HR Strap Grip Replacement

description.text:
FIRST VERSION:
The original strap has a retainer that engages the excess end of the strap from the outside of the strap. With this replacement the retainer engages the leftover of the belt with two pivots —instead of one— from the inside of the belt.

The piece is slightly curved and the pivots point diverging from each other, so it is necessary to use support.

The edges that are in contact with the skin have been chamfered but surely not enough value (it seems necessary to soften them a bit more).

Requires removing the buckle for assembly.

To cover a little the pivots I have painted them with permanent black marker, although I recognize that totally blank also looked well.

The measurements are very fair to pass the belt, probably in a following version I will provide a little more margin.

SECOND VERSION:
A thinner model with only one pivot, as the original one. I'm testing it.
The first version was delicate and the pivots were broken easily.
Now the strap can be printed horizontally, with less support.

title: Casting Flask Mold Box and Mold Cylinder

description.text:
This is a small mold Box and mold Cylinder for making RTV (room Temperature Vulcanization) Silicone rubber molds of small gears and objects. Also included is a Flask and Sprue base for lost wax casting of small parts.

Place an object on the base of the box or cylinder. Small undercuts are ok if your using flexible silicone rubber two part mixes. Mix the silicone rubber and pour it over the part at the base of the box or cylinder. When you remove the silicone rubber form the box or cylinder mold it can then be used as a casting mold for the small part.

The base of the box and cylinder is about 35mm.
The walls are canted out to make it easier to take the mold out of the casting box.

TrueSpace

Design time 7 minutes.
Working with primitives only.
Time from inception to final publishing 13 minutes.

Mold box for small gears. Its often useful to have a small box or cylinder casting flask when making silicone rubber molds of small parts. Just handy to have on hand. The casting flask may be used for lost wax casting.

description.text:
My attempt at a realistic star projection dome.
Includes the 500 brightest stars, in their correct positions, and with relative sizes according to their relative apparent magnitudes.

The sizes of the holes are in steps, according to the rounded up value of their magnitudes, and negative values are substituted with tiny positive values (e.g. Arcturus). The next version should have gradually increasing holes instead (once I get my head around logarithms.

Notes:

I had a hard time getting Simplify3D to print this properly, so went to the fallback of Cura and it was fine.

The blender object is not at all perfect - lots of manifold errors, some 'holes within holes' that create strange artefacts, and a lot of hand made error-correction, but it will do for a first attempt. A lot of cleanup was done in NetFabb, and the resulting stl seems to be ok.

You only need the stl file. The others are provided in case you want to try and improve it within Blender.

The Blender python script creates cylinders of the relative size through the origin pointing in the right direction to intersect the dome.

And then manually deleting the bottom half of the dome.

The dome creation is pretty rubbish - there must be better ways of doing it.

description.text:
This is a new combination of drawers and shelves, which fit best to my needs. The size of the drawers is 12cm x 12cm and is ideal for the storage of electronic or small mechanical parts. But of course there is an infinite number of other uses in the household or workshop as well

It consists of 3 shelves (4, 5 and 6 drawers), 4 connectors which allow lining and stacking up the shelves and 16 different drawers (see pictures for the arrangement of compartments).

Print time of the drawers is roughly 3-5 h, depending on the number of compartments with 0.2mm resolution. Print time of the shelves is 17-19h depending on the number of drawers.

Credit goes to: cruzher for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1666929. I have added wholes on the back of the shelves to save material and print time.

I have added the connectors from Coogrrr (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1862446) and one additional connector.
NOTE: After some more practical test it turned out, the the connectores are too small and it's difficult to make them work. I'll update that soon. The current connectors will not be compatible with the new ones. Also the boxes with get an update, only wth respect to the connections.

The drawers and shelves are still compatible with those published earlier and can be combined.

description.text:
I love this model. The original designer, bendansie, did an incredible job on it, so I really wanted to do something with it for the Remix Challenge. Here is the link to the original design. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:897412. The STL should already be properly positioned to print. I have arranged it flat on the threaded part because that was the orientation that required the least amount of and most easily removed supports.

Please keep in mind that the only file I have personally tested was the high resolution one. I can't vouch for the medium/low files, so those may or may not be functional. I will include the Meshmixer files in case anyone wants to change something.

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Speed: 50mm/s
Top/Bottom Layers: 5
Perimeters: 4

It had to have a ton of supports, but they all pretty much broke away easily. I didn't manage to be able to get the supports out of the tube inside of her, but it doesn't even really seem to affect the water flow much, if at all.

I thought it would be cool to turn it into a shower head, so I sliced it up in Meshmixer, grabbed a STEP file of a threaded cap for a shower arm from McMaster-Carr so that the threads and diameter would be correct. Then. I just put a tube through the middle of her body and pressed the threaded part into it. To get a wall for the holes into her mouth, I just added a cube, resized it to fit inside of her mouth, with a thickness of 5mm, and moved it inside of her face. To make the holes, I just added a pattern to that wall I just made that was a hexagonal grid of 2mm holes with a spacing of 1.5 I think. That's pretty much it. I'm mostly happy with how it turned out, although, it admittedly doesn't make the greatest shower head I've ever used, but I think it looks awesome and I'm blown away that it actually worked.

comments.text: 5/16 is too small for the bee tunnels. Personally changing the design to have 2 "corridors" instead of a bunch of tubes would be a much better approach. Then at least multiple bees could go back and forth and it would prevent them getting stuck. At 5/16" each individual hole is too small but for any bees except the newest nurse bees, which don't typically forage for water. The older bees cannot get into this thing, and if small bees go in both ends of the tube at the same time, they are stuck there till they die as they cant back out with bees trying to come in behind them. This eventually clogs up the tubes. Bees would not read any "one way" signs i put up on each little tube, or i would try it! I mean correct me if im wrong but proper "bee space" is 3/8" not 5/16" right?

description.text: I just loaded burhop's screw into Repetier and simplified the model to reduce the STL file size.

print_settings.Notes:: The Lens's should be printed using a single perimeter, zero infill and no top or bottom layers. Spiral mode if its an option.

description.text:
I can't believe I hadn't seen ThePlanetMike's Warp Core Lamp or any of the others that followed before this week. I immediately downloaded it to start printing but I didn't feel it was up to star feet standards. I quickly brought it in to utopia planitia for a refit and this is what we ended up with.

It is 73% of the originals size but has the same power output. The resolution has been increased by a factor of at least three times and to the point that the facets are no longer visible. All parts now fit on a 100mm x 100mm bed.

In addition to increasing the resolution I have done the following:

The thin round posts are no longer printed. They are now replaced with 5mm diameter steel bars (metal braces I had lying around from the back of Ikea shelving units (now called HEJNE)). You could also use stainless steel automotive brake line tubing.

The ribbed "Vertical Tension Members" are now printed on their sides for a better finish and easier printing. They have a hole down the center for a piece of metal coat hanger wire as a support and to keep them all in line.

The "Magnetic Constrictor Lens" has been remodelled to be a solid which you only print the one perimeter, no infill and no top or bottom layers.

The lens inside the "Warp Reaction Chamber" is now one solid piece that you only print one perimeter, no infill and no top or bottom layers.

The "Phase Adjustment Coils" have been remodelled entirely without the round posts or the vertical tension members.

The "Reactant Injectors" have been entirely remodelled to have no intersecting faces.

The "Warp Reaction Chamber" has had some remodelling on the interior to use less plastic.

The Lamp base has been remodelled to be high resolution. I has a wire hole at the back for the power cord.

The only part that requires support is the "Warp Reaction Chamber".

The entire thing prints very quickly especially the single wall lens's.

UPDATE: Jan 2, 2017 : Added "Lamp Base.stl" to allow it to be used as a table lamp like the original one was intended. I also updated the Blend file with the new base.

UPDATE: Feb 6, 2017: Created http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2090708 which is the light diffuser I used inside the model.

https://theledroom.wordpress.com/2017/02/13/ncc-1701-d-warp-core/

Printer:

Tantillus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Notes:

Print the Warp Reaction Chamber using support is recommended.

The Lens's should be printed using a single perimeter, zero infill and no top or bottom layers. Spiral mode if its an option.

Minimum printed parts:
1 - Reaction Chamber
1 - Reaction Chamber Lens
2 - Magnetic Constrictor Lens's
6 - Vertical Tension Members
2 - Reactant Injectors (or 1 - Reactant Injector and 1 - Lamp Base)
0 - Phase Adjustment Coils

For each additional section added you will need the following:
1 - Phase Adjustment Coil
1 - Magnetic Constrictor Lens
3 - Vertical Tension Members

To increase the resolution of the original parts I imported them into Blender and marked the sharp edges and then set the multi-resolution modifier to work. They are not applied in the Blend file so you can go in and adjust the resolution to your liking.

The parts that I completely remodelled are also done the same way but start off at a higher resolution.

comments.text: That is intentional and it is explained in the instructions how to print them. You only print a single perimeter, zero infill and no top or bottom layers. This will produce a single perimeter lens. If it was modelled to be hollow your slicer would try and print the exterior perimeter and an interior perimeter and possible try and fill between them making a messy inconsistent lens. I hope that makes sense. Also I use this technique with all the lens and for the diffusers for the LEDs.

description.text:
Update 2017-03-17: See TNS' make for a nice retention clip modification to the bolt, in case you're worried about or have problems with the bolt loosening while printing.

This make is for a bracket for mounting a camera to the hotbed of Anet A8 printers. The bracket affixes to the top of the H-bracket, below the actual hotbed. We re-use the holes for the linear bearings and an end clamp to attach the mount to the H-bracket. There are two versions of the bracket, one which attaches to either the back right (nearest power supply) or front left. The other version attaches to either the back left (nearest mainboard) or front right. Minimally one bracket needs to be installed. For each bracket you will need: 4x M4 12mm bolts (these will replace the M4 8mm bolts attaching the H-bracket to the bearing), 2x M3 10mm bolts, and 2x 10mm nuts (these attach the clamp). Please note, the clearance under the clamp and the overhang of the bracket is critical to prevent the attachment from crashing into the printer supports. Check clearance on installation and before each use. Damage to your printer is not my responsibility.

When installing the printed bolt, rotate back and forth, advancing slowly through the receiving end until it moves freely. The bolt is designed to stay captive in the bracket, but do not print without a receiving fixture or the head may interfere with the printer supports.

I use this attachment with the articulating arm and Logitech C270 camera mount found in this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1228521 Additional sets of linkages can be printed to extend and raise the camera to suit your needs. Take note of the side clearance and intersection with the X-axis to avoid collision for the full range of Y-axis movement.

Note: The complete stl file is for reference only. If you have LED strip light channel similar to https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B013U9SXOW you can find my holder for it here: https://tinkercad.com/things/bK3DxeW5aVk

Also note: While you'd reasonably expect otherwise, this doesn't work very well with my extruder LED light attachment, at least not with the dynamic range of a camera like the C270. The extruder light will wash out the entire workspace, which is why I've moved to both camera and light as bed attachments.

And one more thing... if you want a right angle mount for the camera, try this one https://tinkercad.com/things/gjRZTl607dx I can remove one whole link of the arm using this instead of the straight mount in the remix source.

Sources:
https://tinkercad.com/things/daBcxj2oYzf
https://tinkercad.com/things/9Ir89Y4WJDz
https://tinkercad.com/things/fAnlcn3zm9h
https://tinkercad.com/things/80Eahrb4l3b
https://tinkercad.com/things/9oY8RhVX3wA

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

0.4mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer

20%

comments.text:
I made one of these recently (left side) and had the issue that the side-mounted Z-Level sensor hit the screw holding the camera, resulting in all kinds of problems.
Changing the GCode start code to this work around this issue nicely:
;Sliced at: {day} {date} {time}
;Basic settings: Layer height: {layer_height} Walls: {wall_thickness} Fill: {fill_density}
;Print time: {print_time}
;Filament used: {filament_amount}m {filament_weight}g
;Filament cost: {filament_cost}
G21 ;metric values
G90 ;absolute positioning
M107 ;start with the fan off
G28 X0
G1 X110 ; home X and move axis to center to make room for camera
G28 Y0
G1 Y110 ; home Y and move axis to center again to make room
G28 Z
G29 ; home Z and start auto-bed-leveling

comments.text: Lighting via a second mounting bracket works fine for me. Yes, I have a diffuser, I think that helps. Second, I try to orient the light to avoid direct reflections into the camera, mounting it on the other end of the H-bracket allows for this. Third, not shown in the pictures, I have another channel of LED lights directly above the work surface using the spare holes in the A8 acrylic, below and behind the top cross piece where the control panel is mounted. I use these https://tinkercad.com/things/6eNxeV0Hg0O brackets to mount that channel. Forth, I use a dimmer (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00A5193J8/) for the LED lights shown in the pictures, which allows me to adjust it for minimal glare. comments.text: on any tricopter or quad oscillation comes from programming and or vibration directly to the fc board. so if this motor is vibrating so hard maybe try to balance the prop using a magnet balancer. i bought a good one at horizon hobby called top flite precision magnetic balancer. wow it worked so nice now all my quads and tricopters fly perfectly and no jello at all. hope that helps you some happy flying ,tommy  ps i am not bragging but i do fly professionally racing quads and have been in the whole drone thing since the inception of putting 4 motors on 2 sticks and having full control.
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: there's vibration from any motor with no prop on it, wth?
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text:
you could have a missing magnet or bent shaft if it has more vibration than the other motors. or poor motors what are they?
there will be harmonic vibration but it should be clean and smooth.
comments.author: moosestang

comments.text: you can get vibrations - but that is just harmonics and it vibrates at certain frequencies of spinning. That's not the issues we have here though.
comments.author: moosestang

comments.text: the issue is not from prop or motor balance, but how powerful the motors are.
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: As RC multirotor pilots, there are three parameters that we can adjust to improve better quadcopter stability based on different situations. These are the coefficients to the 3 algorithms. PID The coefficients basically would change the importance and influence of each algorithm to the output. no motor is to powerful it just need to be programmed correctly. ive used over 14,000kv and as low as 400kv for photo platforms . there is hope do some research.
comments.author: add1ct3dd

comments.text: You don't understand the use case here, and the education is unrequired. These are made for a purpose where N52SH magnets are used in motors, and you get into a feedback loop within the ESC itself due to how powerful the motors for racing quads nowadays are - there's not much we can do except for soft-mounting the FC or the motors. Doing it this way seems like a better method, as this is the source of the vibration.
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: i do understand the issue and there is more ways to address the problem. but if you are using this for vibration feedback then it you may want to make washers from the same for the bottom side or your bolting it to a solid surface and will get the same vibration through the bolts anyway even add grommets around the bolts themself and bore the holes a bit to fit them. i never try to criticize anyone as we all started somewhere. again i would try to say balance your props before putting them on. it could fix everything alone. adding a capacitor can break a loop also if that's what you have going on.
comments.author: add1ct3dd

comments.text: You balance every prop you put on your racing quad?  wow, you have more spare time than me

comments.text: yes it counts when you race and the final is for $250,000.00.  but even if i didn't it is 4 props how long does it take to do. you only need to do this one time. in ten minutes your done. i was just trying to help you out. any reduction of vibration is a great thing so i will actually try this but im going to use ninja flex. thanks for sharing:)

A simple knob to put on top of the lead screw so you can move the extruder arm up/down when the printer is off, for maintenance.

Also makes leveling dual extruders easier. You can move the extruder arm/up down with the knob, and put a small piece of paper under the nozzles. Adjust the bed level until you feel the same amount of drag under each nozzle and you know the bed is correctly leveled. Do that in all four corners and you're all set!

The threads are a bit tight, so you shouldn't need to print the nut, but if the knob screws on too loosely, put the nut underneath and tighten them against each other.

This design is for a simple adapter to connect a Damo 5" dust shroud to a Craftsman 4" grinder. it is likely compatible with other grinders that have a 1.5" (common) mount. The Damo dust shield is available form Amazon, is the cheapest available, and is all metal construction, but it has an odd sized mount that fits no grinder I have ever seen.
The notch allows the clamp to compress the adapter to make a tight fit on the grinder as well as the dust shield.

title: V-Block Jig to Collimate/Calibrate Laser Collimator

description.text:
When I bought my inexpensive laser collimator on eBay, I thought I had scored a bargain. Turns out the laser collimator I bought, itself, needed collimation! The beam from the laser was off center by around 45mm over a distance of 15m. Close, but not good enough for collimation of a Newtonian reflector telescope.

I printed this v-block jig, used hot melt glue to fasten it to a piece of scrap wood, and clamped the assembly to a counter top. I also put a parfocal ring on the laser collimator to give it a square shoulder (this helps when it is inserted into the eyepiece holder on my telescope, but is strictly optional).

The v-block jig keeps the laser collimator aligned securely while you turn the barrel. Across the room the beam from the laser sweeps out a circle on the wall. Adjust the 3 set screws on the collimator to make the circle on the wall as small as possible.

Dimensions are adjustable in the SCAD file, but I found this size to fit the common laser collimator from China that is sold under many brand names.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Slides over the Proxxon MB140S drill stand to allow two laser line modules to project a cross at the drill point, making lining up your work significantly easier.

The laser modules used are standard HLM1230 (search for "5v laser line" and you'll find them). Using two line modules instead of one cross module ensures the cross remains on the same spot regardless of height.

The mount is kept in place with the stand's tightening handle on one side (around the handle, ensuring there's no pressure on the mount itself), and an optional M5 bolt on the other side to prevent warping.

Designed using Blender. I've included the original file. Enjoy!

Notes:

Printed upside-down using CraftWare. Added supports for the large overhanging structures, the bridges between the laser modules (should've stretched those all the way to make printing easier in hindsight) and one in the middle of each laser module for the small downwards pointing stops.

Cleaning up

After removing the supports I used a file to clean up the inside, which was needed for a proper fit. The laser module mounts were a bit tight, but removing the warning label from the laser module resulted in a perfect fit. Just remember not to stare into the laser with your remaining eye and you'll be fine.

Laser modules

The fiddly little stops at the end were designed so you can still rotate the lens with a pair of pliers while it's in there (best to keep them powered off while doing so!). Focusing is done by rotating the module while keeping the lens in place. Wire them both up to 5V and you're done!

description.text:
This is a ducted cooling system. Name sums it up.
It's designed to attach to a 20x40mm V-Rail.
the fans are Sunon 40x40x28mm MagLev (GM1204PQV1-8A)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00118ZWYY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The tubing can be any 1" ID spiral pipe, this is what I used: http://www.ducting.com/ambient-air/dehumidifier-ducts/pvc-flexduct-general-purpose-blue.html
NOTE: On request I have assembled this using standard CPAP hose, it works fine but with less airflow.

The cooling shrouds are missing, I am waiting on the delivery of my dual tool Flex3Drive before I can get the measurements going; However, the intake/exhaust manifolds should bolt onto any 40mm fan housing.

UPDATE: I have added the lower intake model as well as some images of the system installed and running. I will likely create some kind of hose clamp to keep everything in place and to arrest vibrations. I will post the stl when I have it finished :)

UPDATE: I added an intake manifold for a smaller format AC unit. This one has some threads I am experimenting with to make hose connection easier.

UPDATE: I also added the hose clamp that I have been using to keep everything neat and tidy :)

title: Star Wars X-Wing LANDING PAD for Millenium Falcon

description.text:
As I´m collecting the X-Wing Game Models, I needed a nice way to display them. After finding the really nicely designed Landing Pad for the x-Wing shuttle (#962093) from Jabberwock, I decided to give something back to Thingiverse!
And this is, what came out :-) ... the Landing Pad near the filling station - Spaceships need fuel or whatever, too - got three different parking-positions: One with the front of the Falcon to the tower building, one with the rear facing the tower,.. ready to lift of. And the third is on top of the exhaust funnel. Smaller Crafts can "fly" over the Falcon this way :-).

This Pad is mainly ment for the Millenium Falcon,... but it also fits a lot of other Ships from the x-Wing collection. The cargo boxes are supporting the Falcon, as it seems nobody on board was willing to lower the landing gear. Also they make the scene a bit more lifely.

If you enjoy this one, just let me know.... if your are looking forward to designing your own modul: I did include the baseplate incl. the grid to make the texture. Also there is an additional Block for rebuilding/repairing the surfaceplates like the fan-grid (if not wanted) and an aditional Socket where the plug of the ships get insertet.

And, ....I´d be really be glad to get informed about you modifiing it :-) ... the more varieties, the better :-) Let there be spaceports everywhere!

I did printe mine on a Flashforge Dreamer, changing the filament while printing to get the red "attention, building" stripes into the grey PLA color.

description.text:
6DOF headtracking clips to be used with FreeTrack, TrackHat or other similar headtracking systems.

Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62827.

I created two versions of clips to keep the two halves of the arms together. One version leaves the LEDs exposed while the other is to be used as a light diffuser. The diffuser clips should be printed with white filament for obvious reasons :)

Initially I created the arm clips to fit exactly over the 8mm section of the arms but my printer isn't perfectly calibrated and there was an extra layer of plastic from the arm supports so I also made a version with an 8.7mm inner section that fits perfectly over the arms.

So far I've only created a headphone clip because I had some old USB headphones lying around and I figured it would be easier to power the LEDs from the headphones instead of using batteries.

I will also create a head mounted clip some time in the future.

title: Mini Bit Driver Enclosure for keychains for 4.5mm bits

description.text:
I really really love multitools! However, I'm not a big fan of the 2D philips head driver that comes with my Leatherman Squirt and my Gerber Dime. Since I have a bunch of mini-bit drivers around (the 4.5mm size) I decided to make and share a little keychain companion for my favorite EDC tool.

Step 1. Find a 4.5mm bit that you need to have with you everywhere. Most maker types will have a few sets laying around - if you don't have any then check out your local HW, Electronics, or even dollar store for a set. Budget $1 to $3.

Step 2. Print it with 100% infill - add in your bit and

Step 3. Add to your keychain or EDC multi tool ring.

7mm (7.1mm actually) version available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2009124

Printer:

Maker Select i3 and PowerSpec Ultra

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This is a ~10-15 minute print even with 100% infill.

The fit should be snug and tightness should favor the part that holds the bit when you use it. Some minimal filing may be needed.

Troubleshooting:

  1. Laying the design flat and printing both parts in one works best for me (for overall strength of part) on my i3 but that may not be the case for all printers so I split the design up into PartA and PartB if you want to print separately.

  2. If you have trouble with bridging of part laying flat, try printing PartA and PartB with hole for bit part oriented flat on bed (rotate in your slicer SW).

  3. If the part is too snug - then scale the size in the slicer SW up by one or two percent and try again. (luckily it's only a 10-15 minute print and less than a meter of filament).

  4. If the part is too loose - scale the size in the slicer SW down by one or two percent and try again.

print_settings.Notes:: It's pretty chunky so variations in resolution and infill should be well accepted. It was designed so that no supports are required

description.text:
A friend mentioned their cats were pretty good at opening their interior sliding door. They described how a flip-down retainer could probably keep it in position. What I came up with was a slim assembly that can stay out of the way until you want to use it, with a fingercatch and some bumps and detents to retain it in a stowed position when not in use.

It's quite rugged, even made with PLA - although I wouldn't suggest it as a security apparatus. I realized it could also be used as a flip-down coat hook, so have made a couple of small adjustments which I'll load into Thingiverse as a remix of this version.

The 'small' version of this device only needs 10mm of clearance from the wall. The 'large' version is 40% bigger, so would need 14mm.

A #6 screw will work well in the small version, whereas a #8 (or maybe even a #10) would work with the larger one.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

30%

Notes:

It's pretty chunky so variations in resolution and infill should be well accepted. It was designed so that no supports are required

Just a little clean up of the edges with a file or sandpaper will help it to work well.

Load the latch piece in from the back. When screwed to your wall or baseboard, the latch is well retained. (use a hollow-wall anchor if you're mounting on drywall of course.

Multiple opens and closings before mounting makes the operation smoother. Particularly for the large ones, you can lightly sand the bumps on the latch if you want it to snap into stowed mode a little easier, but it doesn't appear to be necessary.

comments.text: I'm using this on my motorhome to hold the sliding closet doors shut. The "large" version fits 4 small command strips on the back pretty well to stick to the mirror door.

author: kolovitz

print_settings.Notes:: Print on their sides.  Depending on your printing it may need some type of support to keep it from falling.  I didn't need it on my printer.

description.text:
Cell Phone Charging Stand

My wife asked that I make this and then sketched a rough idea of what it should look like. I always jump on these as I remember the “What do we need a 3D printer for?” statements.

Well, I designed this to be like her picture. I wanted to make it so it could be expanded for more shelves. While that could still be done I never needed to add the extra base. I was going to use dove-tail joints but I saw another holder (I sorry I don’t remember who, but if you know who it is, let me know and I will add it) joint that I liked better. I incorporated it into my design as I wanted to have removable shelves (breakage, color change – whatever)

Printer:

Geeetech i3 pro c

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print on their sides. Depending on your printing it may need some type of support to keep it from falling. I didn't need it on my printer.

I got it all printed out. The first two shelves were kind of tight, but the still slid in. I’m just not sure they would come out. I edited the shelf and made the connector a little smaller so it would fit. The last shelf fit perfectly!

I presented it to my wife who then said she wasn’t sure of the ‘color’. As you all know, it isn’t a quick job printing out the parts on something this big. So, what could I do?...... At first I tried to spray paint it in white – oh, what a mistake! It looked horrible, maybe I was going to have to reprint it.

I have admired some of the prints that others get, and one person revealed his secret, XTC-3D. A brush-on coating for 3D printed parts. I ordered some on EBay (24 oz. for around $24 US).

I did not take all the steps ‘required’ in prepping for a good coating. I did it the fast and ‘anything is better that what it looks like now’ attitude. A quick coating, not covering everything – just what was going to show.

Well it turned out better than expected. I then spray painted white. It looks good. It smoothed all the bumps, even made the shelves impossible to remove now as it filled in most of the opens spaces between parts. The one shelf I waited to install, as it has a screw hole for mounting, had to have the interconnecting points cleaned with a file and Xacto knife.
In the end, we didn’t use the screw mounting. We just got some double-sided tape that is meant for picture frames (14-pound load rated) and stuck it to the kitchen wall to keep our phones from getting wet by the sink.

title: MK2 Force Perpendicular Rods Prusa i3 MK2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
More Things at http://prusamk2.com
Join our FACEBOOK Group too: https://www.facebook.com/groups/prusai3mk2owners/
With these 2 pieces you can get your y carriage perpendicular every time.
The split rods are 170mm in length and clip on over the 10mm threaded rods.

Note: These go between the nuts so a nut touches each end of this printed piece.

How to: Loosen the nuts on the rods so that you can clip on the split 170mm covers. Hand tighten the nuts so they press against the rods firmly. Tighten the back side double nuts against the main z frame. Your Prusa i3 Mk2 has no choice but to be perpendicular. It’s simple math…

There is also a pre sliced version with brim included that can easily be printed in PLA on your Prusa i3 Mk2 available if needed.

Note: There is a side to be used for cable management and another for the right side.
Print them both on end with a brim of 10 or so perimeters.

comments.text: If you want to get as close as possible to 170mm, then print at 0.2mm layer height. However, the total distance is less important than having two rods identical in length. So if they are both ~170.1mm or ~170.4mm when printing at 0.3mm layer height, its OK. Anything less than 170mm may result in not being able to reach the front calibration points and its possible you will clamp the smooth rods too much when tightening and damage the 3D-printed corner pieces. You can always shim the rods with paper spacers if needed.
comments.author: alomex21

comments.text: Layer height does not matter. just print it to 170mm in height.
comments.author: alomex21

comments.text:
• Layer height does matter, as the printer cannot print a partial layer. The total height of an object MUST be a multiple of the layer height. If you try and print these at 170mm total height, using the Prusa Optimal 0.15mm layer height, you won't get the correct result. Calculator tells me that you would need 1133 and 1/3 layers of 0.15mm to make 170mm total. There is also no correction for how "squished" your first layer is.

  • Even if you have both sides here exactly the same, it does not guarantee that your frame is perpendicular. A parallelogram has sides of equal lengths, but is not perpendicular. This model does nothing to ensure that your corners are exactly 90 degrees.

description.text:
Flip it down to hang a coat, or hook a clothes hanger over it. Seems suitable in your laundry room, or near your ironing board. Probably good for your workplace too, where you can flip it down to hold your coat during colder weather.

Could probably hold your headphones when you're not using them too. Your VR headset?

Seems to take a #6 wood-screw pretty well.

This started life as door stop for a sliding door, but I realized it would work nicely as a flip-out-of-the-way coat hook too.

So a couple of changes, just to emphasize the hook part, and perhaps retain a hanger better if you were to hand a shirt or jacket on it, seemed like nice additions.

Makes me think there are likely some other flip-down-to-use applications that we could remix this little guy into. Any ideas?

Pretty forgiving if you need to use a lower resolution, or less infill.

Clean it up a bit with some sandpaper along the edges, smooth out the pivot-pins, and you're good to go.

Open and close a few times. I've found that this bump-plus-detent retention approach smooths out with use pretty well, so perhaps let it work itself in rather than taking too much material away with sandpaper early and having it a bit loose later on.

print_settings.Notes:: 0.4mm nozzle, 3 shells, 3 top and 3 bottom layers (fewer will be more flexible, more will be more stiff).

description.text:
I muscled the headset buckle on my HTC vive a bit too hard when removing it, and one of the tabs broke. So I measured everything, made a CAD model, and printed this replacement. it works great (yes, I really use it and I'm not worried about the headset coming loose)

IMPORTANT: Use a strong material with some elongation (flex) strength. Mine worked best with Taulman Bridge Nylon. I also tried Taulman Tech-G, but it didn't quite have enough elongation before it would snap. Test it before using it by giving it a reasonable pull / twist, etc. This buckle, like the original, works by flexing and pulling a bit, making the tabs pull tight into the slots.

My best print:

Taulman Bridge Nylon
0.4mm nozzle
0.15 layer height
Oriented on the large, flat, back side
45mm/sec
45 C bed

Use fine supports set at 45 degrees (I used simplify 3D with supports set 1mm^2 threshold). This will make some small supports under the hooks of the tabs so they come out just right to grip the headset. I also set the speed slower when printing the tabs only.

Due to the nature of printing small tabs with nylon, they weren't perfect and the supports hare harder to remove in nylon. I scored them and filed them off patiently to make a good flat edge under the tab.

Very relieved that I don't have to worry about the headset dropping now.

I didn't try ABS, PLA, or other materials. Just use something that can take some pulling and stress...

Have fun!

remixed_from.author: dragonrotors
remixed_from.title: Toad 110 - Micro FPV Quad - (8.5mm Hubsan X4 Motors)

description.text:
This is a remix I did off the original Toad 110 by charlesgershom.

Modified features:
-- Added a 20 degree incline on the lower deck for a CAM+VTX similar to the Eachine TX02.
-- Added a slot on the top deck for the VTX antenna mast to pass through.
-- Added another cross support on the top deck toward the rear for top mount battery support.
-- Moved back some elevated areas on the lower deck so longer flight controllers sit flush.
-- Removed battery mount pegs from lower deck and instead using velcro to mount battery.
-- This camera mount design will limit damage to your VTX antenna since if it bends, it will only bend as far as the top deck, which is a few millimeters away.

Required for Frame Assembly:
4x M3x18mm standoffs (or +/- 2mm)
4x M3 Nuts
4x M3 Screws

Recommended Budget FPV Setup:
-- Flight Controller: Hubsan X4 H107 OEM
-- Motors: Hubsan 8.5x20mm OEM
-- Props: Hubsan H107 OEM
-- Camera: Eachine TX01 25mW AIO
-- Battery: 1S 500mAh

Recommended FPV Racing Setup (1S battery):
-- Flight Controller: F3 Evo Brushed, Beef's Brushed, Micro Scisky
-- Motors: Spintech Sidewinder 8.5x20mm (1S)
-- Props: Walkera QR Ladybird or Afunta Hubsan Transparent Props
-- Camera: Eachine TX01 25mW AIO (indoors) / Eachine TX02 200mW AIO (long range outdoors)
-- Battery: 1S 500mAh

Recommended FPV Racing Setup (2S battery):
-- Flight Controller: F3 Evo Brushed, Micro Scisky
-- Motors: Spintech Sidewinder 8.5x20mm (2S)
-- Props: Walkera QR Ladybird or Afunta Hubsan Transparent Props
-- Camera: Eachine TX02 200mW AIO
-- Battery: 2S 400mAh

ASSEMBLY NOTE: Use hot glue or two tiny zip ties to hold down the camera. When using the Camera+VTX AIO module, the top deck is much higher than the original Toad 110. This will require observing clearance between the props and top deck (and possibly the VTX antenna. Motors may need to sit higher in the motor mount cup, so don't shove them all the way in upon assembly until the clearance is checked with a motor that has a prop installed. I don't have any Walkera QR Ladybird props to check the size, but the Afunta props will fit and allow for free rotation.

ABS with 40% or higher infill on the lower deck is strong enough to survive most crashes. This chassis is pretty thick and strong.

File Antenna Slot

Test fit your Camera+VTX AIO module. I had to file the slot a little bit where the antenna goes through the top deck since the heatshrink on my antenna mast had too much friction to slide in smoothly. YMMV

title: Jig for laying out holes at 0.5 and 1.5" from edge

description.text:
I needed to markup a lot of holes on 1" centers and 1/2" from an edge, so I made this very simple jig to make life easier. It worked well, so just in case it's useful to you, here it is :)

There is a slot in the middle with angled ends for lining up with a distance mark as well as triangular notches at each end. The two holes are conical to give good alignment on an automatic center punch, and there is a lip which aligns with the outer edge. It's really very quick to use compared to measuring and punching by eye.

Update: sorry, I messed up the title, hope this didn't confuse anyone. The first hole is 0.5 inches from the edge, the second hole is at 1.5 inches, i.e. 1" between centers.

author: Kirkian

description.text:
There are several versions of the realacc x210 pod.
It is for the old version.

I am thinking of making a pro version.
That version will have as base the geprc version.

For now I keep the existing ones and I have added 4 new versions all 4 with the step files.
In the stl version are all the holes for the matek pdb, rear opening for power wires and the sides open for the fc. The step files will have no holes so you can ad your own holes in it.
The 4 versions are with 20, 30, 40 cam mount and no cam mount.
In this last version there are some small changes.
The pod is lighter.
The vtx antenna mount is moved further to the back to give more space for the pigtail 90 degree and straight.
The front is a bit longer to protect the fpv cam better.
The mount four the fpv cam is a bit wider from 27.5 to 28mm, made it easier to mount a hs1177 and a runcam swift.
Lens hole is 17mm but as you use flex material what is best for the pod, the gopro lens will fit.
Improved the area under the fpv mount so it is a bit thicker.
Changed the way to mount the pod to the frame. I added opening so you can slide in a M3 nut that is 3mm high. The normal m3 and the nylon nuts will fit. This will make it better to mount the pod.

Names of the new versions are pod, pod 20, pod 30 and pod 40.

I hope that the new versions and the step files help to make changes and that everything fits better.

comments.text:
OK, thanks. on #2, I've had all of the realacc x210 frames (x210,x210 v+, x210 Pro), and they all seem to work better with the battery strap coming in the side, down through the hole, accross the body underneath, back up the other hole & out the other side. It's much more stable and the battery stays in better, likely because it's a bit wider like this than the other way. Also, it leaves room underneath the stack for the receiver, which saves a lot of space, esp in an already cramped frame.
I might try remixing the POD to put some slots on the bottom sodes to fit the strap, though I'm not sure how well it will work because it might not print with more gaps in the bottom!

description.text:
Have you put in 20 years of service in the NCR? Do Caesar's Legionnaires run in fear of you? Then you must be an NCR Vereran Ranger. You're tough as nails and eat your enemies for breakfast and Sugar Bombs for dessert. You deserve the proper side arm! So here is your Sequoia.

This stared as a raw game pull (that model included). I scaled it to the 17.5" long real life gun it was based on.......yeah, it's that big! The I smoothed a lot of things out and added the inscriptions in the barrel, sides of the grip, and bottom of the grip. I prefer to print in ABS for my props so I can acetone weld and smooth. If you do, scale up ~2%. I also included some rounds so you can add them to a bandoleer to further look like a bad-ass.

Now go and cleanse the wasteland with your huge hand cannon!

remixed_from.author: ralis
remixed_from.title: Nerf Peg Board Hook - Double Barrel

remixed_from.author: ralis
remixed_from.title: Nerf Peg Board Hook - Single Barrel

description.text:
I had problems with the original printing reliably, and it turned out there was a single layer height on the pins, causing the rest of the hook to be printed at layer 2 and not adhered to the print bed. The default support settings for slic3r and cura seem to not have support for a single layer.

This remix just eliminates that single extra layer on the pins, causing them to be entirely flat on the print bed, and print reliably without support.

This has both the single and the double length pegboard hooks

My attempt to model the Tiko build volume. Any suggestions or revisions are welcome.

At the default 0.2mm layer height and 25% infill, it would take a theoretical 73.5 hours and 274 meters of filament.
I designed it by taking a hull of 3 circles, and systematically changing the diameter and spacing to match the build volume as close as possible.

title: OpenFlywheelProject Rapidstrike/Stryfe Flywheel Cage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an opensource flywheel cage created for the Nerf Rapidstrike and Nerf Stryfe.
It has been tested in both.

There are four versions of this cage poster here, for highest performance print the 41.5 mm cage. Each cage larger has decreasing performance related to the gap distance listed in the file name.

For high crush systems such as the 41.5 mm and 42 mm cages, motors with very high torque ratings are required.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

You can use rafts if you want, However it will require considerably more post processing that way.
This can be printed in PLA, but due to the high heat generated by the motors, it is best to print in ABS or PETG.
Designed primarily in solidworks.

comments.text: Im planning on printing ABS in the near future, the location right now is my bedroom(about 160sqft or so) at my college apartment. I've read some things on the fumes and id rather not risk any breathing issues. Currently this is the only place I can place it. I have an idea for a venting solution that i will start working on after class today.
comments.author: Diedtrying

comments.text: That's about the space I printed in for abs initially. My .02 is first research what other plastics might work for your application. For instance I settled on PETG which prints relatively easily and doesn't fine quite as bad. I looked for another plastic, mostly because abs is a nightmare to print for larger prints. Otherwise, go look up my knife valve, and use that in line, keep it closed while printing and then open it when done to suck out the fumes. Worked well for me. And then use some tape to seal up your machine, both for heat retention, and to keep the fumes from escaping.
